title: Representing SHM - time to return to equilibrium

content.question: Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> of mass <math alttext="m sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> of mass <math alttext="m sub 2 equals 2 m sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> are each attached to identical horizontal springs. Each block is displaced from equilibrium by an unknown amount and the blocks are released from rest simultaneously, undergoing simple harmonic motion. A student claims that Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> will make its first return to its equilibrium position before Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> first returns to its equilibrium position. Is this claim correct? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because the maximum force exerted by the spring on Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is less than that exerted on Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

Yes, because the period of oscillation for Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is less than that of Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.
No, because the initial displacements of the blocks are unknown.
No, because the springs are identical.

content.answer: Yes, because the period of oscillation for Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is less than that of Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.
